learning_outcomes.description: Implement object-oriented programs according to their specifications.
Design, implement and document object-oriented programs using language features such as inheritance, interfaces, polymorphism, exceptions and I/O.
Design and implement test components for object-oriented programs.
Analyse code to judge whether it follows good programming practice.
Write, interpret and critique specifications for program modules (e.g. classes or interfaces).

assessments.due_date:
Week 2 Mon - Week 13 Mon

Submission due date and time is 1:00pm Monday each week. 

Due to Cyclone Alfred, Week 2 is due 1:00pm Friday 14 March and Week 3 is cancelled. Due to a public holiday, Week 9 is due 1:00pm Tuesday 6 May.
assessments.category: Computer Code, Quiz, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
The due date and time will be before 1:00pm the following Monday of each week, commencing with the first (Week 1) set due before 1:00pm on the Monday of Week 2; and the last (Week 12) set due before 1:00pm on the Monday of Week 13.

  • Due to TC Alfred, Week 2 is now due before 1:00pm on Friday 14th March.
  • Due to TC Alfred, there are no Week 3 Ed Lessons (there are now only 11 sets of Ed Lessons); Week 4 Ed Lessons are due before 1:00pm on the Monday of Week 5 (24th March), as normal.
  • Due to the public holiday on Monday 5th May, the Week 9 set will instead be due before 1:00pm on Tuesday 6th May.

You will be given sets of simple practical Java programming problems to solve during the semester. These problem sets will be delivered and submitted via the Ed Lessons online environment. Each set of problems will reinforce concepts delivered in the course. Refer to the assessment description on Blackboard.

A link to this environment is available on Blackboard.

This assessment task is designed to develop students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct and at the very least will harm the student's own learning in their development for other assessments.
assessments.submission_guidelines: These problem sets will be delivered and submitted via the Ed Lessons online environment. A link to this environment is available on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Assignments are used to assess the practical skills of students on non-trivial, but reasonably well-defined problems.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop code is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online via Gradescope unless otherwise specified for a particular assessment item. Details will be provided with the assignment specification.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: The exam will be similar in format to previous semesters and will cover all course content. You may use past exams as practice questions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
